Brief Description: understanding and applying abstract concepts such as analogies and metaphors
Description: Abstraction is the ability to think flexibly about ideas rather than just concrete circumstances, including words and events. The ability to engage in abstract thinking is essential to many forms of human expression, including mathematics, science, literature, play, humor etc. Abstract thinking includes skills such as the ability to think about numbers without having something to count, and to play “make-believe” or to tell an imaginary story (e.g., fairy tales). Without abstract thinking, it is difficult to expand thoughts and ideas beyond the concrete objects, limiting creative problem-solving.

Brief Description: applying skills and abilities to achieve academic goals
Description: Academic motivation is an individual’s general commitment to scholarly/learning activities. It includes not only the determination to acquire knowledge and skills in school, but also the development of the tools necessary to successfully perform in the academic context. While often reduced to “grades,” this method fails to capture the commitment necessary to establish and maintain appropriate subject level knowledge and skills (e.g., mathematics, science, language, history, etc.), as well as the willingness to flexibly and adaptively use general and specific resources (e.g., mentors, libraries, collaboration, etc.) needed to succeed.

Brief Description: Quality and consistency of schoolwork
Description: Observable patterns in the student's work quality, including effort, accuracy, and meeting academic expectations

Brief Description: maintaining physical and cognitive activity
Description: For successful adaptation, it is critical that individuals apply activity levels consistent with the tasks and the environment. Activity consists of all manner of functions, including gross and fine motor activity as well as cognition, emotions, and other aspects of biological and social functioning.

Brief Description: Interactions with teachers and staff
Description: How the student relates to and interacts with teachers, administrators, and other school personnel, including trust, respect, and comfort.

Brief Description: The ability to make choices about and take an active role in one's life path, rather than solely being the product of one's circumstances. Agency requires the intentionality and forethought to derive a course of action and adjust course as needed to reflect one's identity, competencies, knowledge and skills, mindsets, and values.
Appearing awake and mentally present
Description: The extent to which a student appears rested

Brief Description: managing responses when provoked
Description: Anger is a typical experience that reflects the strong expression of annoyance, frustration, or displeasure. While anger is a typical emotion, reactions can vary from well-regulated and appropriate, to poorly modulated, disruptive, and even violent.

Brief Description: initiating actions to support interests goals and desires
Description: Aggression is the full spectrum of assertive behaviors, with assertiveness representing the forceful interaction with the environment to obtain needs or goals. Assertiveness includes a broad range of behaviors that vary widely based on individual differences, culture, and context. These contexts may include school, work, athletics and other competitive activities, and in some cases, it can lead to forms of violence, associated with personal protection, criminal activity, and war. A key to successful adaptation is the flexible and appropriate application of assertiveness in the course of work and play.

Brief Description: having attachments to family peers and adults
Description: Attachment is the strong, bilateral, emotional connection between humans (and other animals). Initially, this connection is with the individual’s primary caregivers, but it rapidly expands to include others important to the life of the individual. In humans, attachments usually begin in the first days of life, becoming more socially, emotionally, and behaviorally complex over time.

Brief Description: sustaining attention and concentration
Description: Attention is the ability to focus interests, cognition, emotions and/or other resources on a particular object, goal, idea, effort, activity, etc. Attention and concentration are cognitive processes that allow for the selection and focus on a particular task or object (including goals, ideas, etc.) for some period of time. It is usually easier to pay attention when there is strong interest, feeling or commitment to a particular topic or goal. Concentration and attention can vary by environment and other concomitant obligations. Most children and adults can maintain concentration on an important topic for 30-40 minutes. Attention and concentration often require active avoidance of distraction. Failure to maintain attention often leads to mistakes and interruptions in important tasks.

Brief Description: Belonging is about building strong relationships with peers and adults, group acceptance and group identity. The need for belonging is central to our early development in our attachment to our caregivers and continues throughout our lives in a variety of ways. Humans are social creatures, and group belonging is essential for well-being and survival.
involvement as victim perpetrator or encouraging observer
Description: Bullying, the most common form of interpersonal violence, is a recurrent pattern of behavior that takes place when one individual takes advantage of a power differential to cause physical or emotional harm to another. Participants in bullying may be victims, perpetrators, and victim-perpetrators, as well as active and passive by-standers/observers. Each of those involved in bullying can suffer adverse consequences from the experience.

Brief Description: Engagement in learning
Description: The student's active involvement in classroom discussions, activities, and learning opportunities.

Brief Description: feeling comfortable participating and being oneself in class
Description: Classroom comfort reflects how safe and comfortable a student feels engaging in class activities, sharing ideas, and making mistakes in front of others. High comfort supports participation and learning risk-taking. Low comfort may show as reluctance to speak, fear of embarrassment, or avoidance of activities that draw attention, even when the student understands the material.

Brief Description: Demonstrate ability to work effectively and respectfully with diverse teams; Exercise flexibility and willingness to be helpful in making necessary compromises to accomplish a common goal; Assume shared responsibility for collaborative work, and value the individual contributions made by each team member
following rules and instructions adaptively
Description: Compliance is adherence to rules or directions, consistent with the setting or environment (e.g., school, work, home, etc.) in order to achieve goals and objectives.

Brief Description: Arguments and disagreements
Description: The frequency and intensity of verbal or physical conflicts, arguments, or hostile interactions with peers or adults.

Brief Description: Methods for managing stress
Description: The approaches the student uses to handle stressful situations, including whether strategies are effective and appropriate.

Brief Description: applying novel strategies to problem-solving
Description: Creativity is the ability to see beyond traditionals constraints and rules, and to allow imagination as well as novel and unique ideas to help solve new problems, offer alternative solutions to existing tasks or problems, and provide unique perspectives on the many aspects of our daily lives.

Category: Kenya BECF Core Competencies for Basic Education
Brief Description: An important outcome of quality education is teaching learners how to think critically. The British Council (2015) identifies three types of thinking: reasoning, making judgements, and problem solving. It is possible for learners to reason in an uncritical way. When learners are empowered with critical thinking, they avoid being subjective, and use logic and evidence to arrive at conclusions. Critical thinking also facilitates exploring new ways of doing things and learner autonomy. Learners learn that for every issue there are multiple perspectives that they can explore, rather than a rigid recall and regurgitation of information.
Seeking out information to better understand a wide range of topic areas and/or obtaining a depth of understanding in one topic area that goes beyond what is required
managing daily self-care routines that support comfort at school
Description: Daily self-care routines include actions that help a student stay comfortable and ready to learn (e.g., basic hygiene, dressing appropriately for the day, managing personal items, and attending to basic needs). Strong routines support independence and peer comfort. Difficulty may show as frequent forgetfulness of basic needs, needing repeated reminders for hygiene-related tasks, or discomfort that interferes with participation.

Category: Room to Read Life Skills Education Learning Outcomes
Brief Description: Girls understand the steps in decision-making and goal-setting and have developed skills of independence and initiative in making choices. Girls make short- and long-term goals for their schooling and future careers by examining issues and ideas from various perspectives. Girls analyze and discuss decisions points and give examples of steps they follow and why they make a specific decision or goal.
inappropriate or inaccurate interpretation of events experiences and thoughts
Description: Perception of reality, or “reality testing,” is the ability to consistently discern the difference between facts and fantasy or other imagined thought content and perceptions. While each of us may have a vivid imagination and fantasies, except under extraordinary circumstances, we can readily distinguish between reality and that which we imagine. The extraordinary circumstances under which clearly recognizing reality may be impaired, include: extreme stress, during intense grief, when very defensive, and when engaged in intense play or similar activity. In these latter cases, the difficulty distinguishing between reality and fantasy/imagination is usually short-lived and quite specific to the circumstances (e.g., seeing visions of the presence of a recently deceased person). Specific difficulties associated with problems in reality perception include: hallucination (i.e., hearing, seeing, feeling or other sensation in the absence or an actual stimulus), delusion (i.e., a false belief), illusion (i.e., gross misperception of an actual stimulus), etc.

Brief Description: maintaining dietary intake and nutrition
Description: Eating is a complex behavior that has both nutritional and social components. The nutritional component is the appropriate consumption of both calories (for energy) and the elements of the diet (protein, vitamins, minerals, fats, carbohydrates, etc.) necessary for maintaining healthy function. There are two main social components of eating: the social interactions associated with the preparation and consumption of food, and the cultural elements associated with menus, dining schedules, and food consumption (e.g., Kosher, Hallal, vegan/vegetarian, etc.) Food preparation and dining are often social experiences that reflect culture and other expectations for cooperation and sharing of both food and conversation, as well as engagement in a variety of behaviors directly associated with eating, such as use of specific utensils (chopsticks, fork, spoon, hands, etc.), cleanliness, order, and the nature of physical presence (e.g., sitting in a chair, standing, walking, sitting cross-legged on the floor, use of a particular hand, etc.) Appropriate participation in all elements of eating are important for health and happiness.

Brief Description: Amount of energy invested in schoolwork
Description: The degree to which the student applies themselves to academic tasks, tries their best, and demonstrates genuine investment in the quality of their work.

Brief Description: managing threshold and intensity of emotional responses
Description: Emotions are strong feelings derived from internal and external stimuli that are reflected in mood and responsive to environmental factors and relationships with others. These feelings may range broadly and include joy, happiness, love, euphoria, anxiety, sadness, fear, loss, and many more. These emotions play a critical role in social communication, motivation, and protection. However, in order to maintain adaptive functioning, emotions require careful regulation in terms of type, intensity, and duration of emotional expression, each of which must be sensitive to environmental, social, and cultural factors.

Brief Description: identifying and labeling own emotions
Description: Emotional awareness is the ability to recognize and understand one's own emotions as they are happening. It involves distinguishing between different feeling states (e.g., frustration vs. anger) and understanding the causes of these feelings. This is a foundational skill for emotion regulation.

Brief Description: Appropriateness of emotional display
Description: The degree to which the student's emotional expressions match the situation and are communicated in socially appropriate ways.

Brief Description: recovering from setbacks and returning to a steady emotional state
Description: Emotional resilience is the ability to bounce back after disappointment, conflict, mistakes, or other challenges. Resilient students can regain composure and re-engage with learning, sometimes with brief support. Low resilience may appear as lingering upset, repeatedly dwelling on setbacks, or difficulty returning to baseline after relatively small challenges.

Brief Description: Emotional well-being refers to aspects of optimal mental health that, if not evident in a child at this early stage, could predict more serious mental health problems, such as anxiety – a potential sign of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD); sadness, a potential precursor of depression; or the inability to control aggressive impulses – a precursor of oppositional and conduct disorders.
having sensitivity to the feelings and needs of others
Description: Empathy is the ability to understand the emotions and emotional state of another person (and some animals.)

Brief Description: Approaching daily life with energy, excitement and spontaneity.
showing interest and involvement in learning activities
Description: Engagement with learning reflects how much a student is mentally and behaviorally involved in instruction and learning tasks. In the classroom, it may show up as attending to lessons, participating appropriately, asking questions, and staying involved even when tasks are challenging. Low engagement may look like frequent disengagement, minimal participation, or avoidance of learning activities.

Brief Description: Seeking and processing education and occupation information guided by knowledge of the self (e.g., identifying specific occupations that are of interest to you)
clearly communicating needs, questions, and concerns
Description: Expressing needs and questions refers to a student’s ability to tell others what they need in a clear, appropriate way (e.g., asking for clarification, requesting a break, or reporting a concern). Strong skills support independence and reduce frustration. Difficulty may be seen when a student stays silent when confused, communicates indirectly, or expresses needs through behavior rather than words.

Brief Description: communicating with speech and gestures
Description: Expressive Language includes words and sounds, powerfully augmented by non-verbal communication, including gestures, body posture, facial expression etc. There are many subtle elements that enhance the breadth, depth and nuance of expressive language. These include rate, rhythm, volume, prosody, and tone of speech, as well as vocabulary and word choice. Effective expressive communication requires the flexible, skillful combination of gestures and spoken words. It takes considerable effort to communicate functionally, yet remarkably, even from early life, typically developing individuals are able to express to others their ideas, feelings, wants, and needs. These skills grow in complexity over the course of the lifespan, however, there is considerable variability amongst individuals that depends on biological make-up, cognitive ability, environmental factors, and cultural/social experiences.

Brief Description: Acting in ways that are intended to be unbiased and fair to everyone
performing the full spectrum of fine motor activities
Description: Fine motor skills are represented by small motor movements, most commonly the product of the small muscle groups of the hands, fingers, toes, face and neck. It takes a great deal of coordination to effectively use the many muscle groups involved in fine motor activity. The coordination includes input from the kinesthetic, visual, and somatosensory systems, as well as practice for complex tasks, such as writing, drawing, speaking, and facial expression.

Brief Description: Adapting to new environments and making adjustments to accommodate changes
Handling difficulty without becoming overwhelmed
Description: The student's ability to cope with challenging situations, setbacks, or obstacles without becoming excessively upset, shutting down, or acting out.

Brief Description: having thoughts and feelings about the future
Description: Future outlook is the ability and willingness to flexibly think about and imagine the future, and adaptively anticipate what is to come in the near-and-short-term. A perspective on the future is usually accompanied by an attitude about what opportunities, threats, and goals lie ahead, an attitude that can shape actions and preparations related to potential future events.

Category: USAID YouthPower Action Key Soft Skills for Cross-Sectoral Youth Outcomes
Brief Description: Goal orientationis defined as the motivation and ability to make viable plans and take action toward desired goals (Lippman et al., 2014a). Goal orientation was conceptualized in the workforce and SRH literature as educational and career aspirations, expectations about one’s ability to achieve specific accomplishments in the future, goal setting and planning skills. Goal orientation is closely tied with positive self-concept, since it relates to individuals’ beliefs about their abilities to accomplish specific goals. Goal-orientation was supported by the literature as related to three of the SRH outcomes studied for youth and was endorsed by some experts.
performing the full spectrum of gross motor activities
Description: Gross motor skills are generally large amplitude motor movements, most commonly the product of the larger muscle groups of the limbs and trunk. Since there are many muscle groups involved in gross motor activity they must be coordinated to be effective. The coordination includes input from the kinesthetic, visual, and somatosensory systems, as well as practice for complex tasks, including walking. Skilled gross motor activity sets the stage for success in many areas including athletics, dance, cycling, driving etc.

Brief Description: Having a growth mindset means understanding that intelligence can be developed.
managing recurring habits
Description: Habits are well-practiced routines that are essential for managing daily function by creating efficiency and effectiveness processes for managing recurring tasks and addressing familiar problems. Habits are automatic behaviors, but, when necessary for successful adaptation, can be modified to accommodate changing circumstances.

Brief Description: Approaching difficulties constructively
Description: The extent to which a student responds to obstacles or problems with a solution-oriented mindset rather than avoidance or frustration.

Brief Description: Asking for support appropriately
Description: The student's ability to recognize when help is needed and to seek assistance from appropriate sources in constructive ways.

Brief Description: Willingness to assist others
Description: The student's inclination to offer help, support, and assistance to peers and adults without being asked

Brief Description: not maintaining appropriate cleanliness
Description: Hygiene is a group of practices that are primarily designed to maintain cleanliness and prevention of disease. However, in addition to a health component, there is a strong social component to hygiene that is culturally driven. This includes grooming practices, attire, and general standards of tidiness. To meet the basic health obligations for hygiene requires regular washing and bathing of the body as well as washing clothes. To meet the social obligations of hygiene not only includes cleanliness, but also attending to standards for physical presentation. This includes various elements and depends on culture and environment. Some factors may include the type of clean clothing, cleaning teeth, arranging hair, trimming and painting nails, the use of makeup, management of body odor, etc.

Brief Description: Age-appropriate self-reliance
Description: The student's ability to function autonomously, solve problems independently, and take initiative without excessive adult support

Brief Description: Initiative can be conceptualized as the “active ingredient” that motivates individuals to operate as positive and successful actors in their own lives and in systems. Initiative hinges on personal agency31 and an internal locus of control, a belief that outcomes depend on one’s own actions rather than fate, chance, or others. It is linked to enterprise, taking charge, follow-through, determination, and leadership. It also facilitates effective engagement within organizational contexts. Although initiative and achievement motivation are related, they are distinct skills. Initiative relates to any type of “take charge” action such as picking up litter on the street, whereas achievement motivation is linked to a desire to succeed and is associated with setting long-term academic and career goals and following this pursuit in spite of obstacles that may occur along the way. Initiative correlates with mastery orientation to achievement and relates to the personality traits of Openness to Experience and Conscientiousness.
recognizing and sharing truths and falsehoods with others
Description: Integrity is the commitment to being honest and principled in one’s approach to problem-solving, as well as in social interactions. There are two major failures in integrity: 1) Errors of commission - specifically being dishonest or representing an untruth; and, 2) Errors of omission - specifically withholding important information required for a fair and balanced approach to a specific circumstance or situation.

Category: Hilton & Pellegrino Clusters of 21st Century Competencies
Brief Description: Flexibility, adaptability, artistic and cultural appreciation, personal and social responsibility (including cultural awareness and competence), appreciation for diversity, adaptability, continuous learning, intellectual interest and curiosity
Engagement with activities and life
Description: A student's capacity to feel interested in activities, experience pleasure and enjoyment, and approach life with curiosity rather than apathy

Brief Description: Curiosity and enthusiasm for new knowledge
Description: The student's apparent enjoyment of learning, desire to explore new topics, and engagement with educational content beyond minimum requirements.

Brief Description: reacting to frustration or annoyance
Description: Irritability is a feeling of agitation and annoyance in response to a stimulus or stress. Irritability can be an appropriate response to a offensive social or physical stimulus that becomes problematic, however, the appropriate intensity of such a response varies based on the intensity and persistence of the stimulus, as well as the social context. Irritability can range from a mild facial expression or gesture to a massive outpouring of emotions.

Brief Description: Prosocial and caring behavior
Description: A student's tendency to be kind, considerate, helpful, and caring toward peers—including offering help, sharing, and showing concern for others' feelings

Brief Description: Knowledge is the sets of facts, information, or understanding about oneself, others, and the world. Skills are the learned abilities to carry out a task with intended results or goals. Building academic knowledge and skills is a key developmental task during early and middle childhood, although it occurs through all stages of development.
initiative innovation vision leading by example doing the right thing/making the right choice
using errors and feedback to improve understanding and performance
Description: Learning from feedback and mistakes reflects a student’s ability to reflect on errors, adjust strategies, and improve over time. It includes noticing patterns in mistakes and applying feedback to new tasks. Difficulty may show as repeating the same errors, avoiding review of mistakes, or viewing errors as personal failure rather than information for growth.

Brief Description: Acquiring and integrating new information
Description: The student's general ability to understand, retain, and make use of new information and skills presented in instruction.

Brief Description: adopting and developing strategies for learning new material
Description: Learning strategies are the full spectrum of creative, flexible approaches and tools for the acquisition of new knowledge. It includes all facets of learning in school and extra-curricular settings, as well as how one approaches learning life skills at home and in the community (e.g., music, dance, sports, game playing, cooking, cleaning, community social functions, riding bicycles, magic tricks, etc.) For skillful adaptation, effective and efficient learning strategies must vary with development, experience, and the nature of the learning task. Examples of learning strategies include changing oral tasks into written tasks, breaking large problems into a sequence of small problems, etc.

Brief Description: understanding spoken information during lessons and discussions
Description: Listening comprehension reflects how well a student understands spoken language in real time, such as teacher explanations, peer comments, and classroom discussions. Strong skills include identifying main ideas and relevant details and responding appropriately. Difficulty may appear as confusion after oral instructions, off-topic responses, or needing information repeated even when attention appears adequate.

Brief Description: Student demonstrates time management when organizing and planning project activities with a team or when organizing and managing themselves and individual class assignments and homework. Time management is inherent in almost all assignments.
cognitively and mechanically performing arithmetic operations
Description: Math, or arithmetic, is the ability to manage numerical and/or quantitative ideas, both conceptually and in graphical representations. Mathematical skills evolve over time, beginning using numbers for the concrete counting of objects, evolving into the appreciation that numbers can representing various constructs such as quantity, time, space, etc. Success with math can be confounded by writing difficulty as “imprecise” presentation of numbers leads to errors.

Brief Description: expending effort and employing strategies for remembering and recalling
Description: Memory is a complex biological function that allows for the brain to store and recall factual information and related emotional and other factors that are linked to the facts. There are multiple forms of memory to account for different uses of the stored information. Short-term memory is for the management of information that is needed temporarily to complete a brief task. For intermediate level activities, information from short-term memory is transferred to working memory for more extended task completion. Long-term memory is information that may be used again and again and/or over extended periods of time. The durability of a particular memory depends a great deal on the importance of that which is being remembered, the linkages of that memory to other important factors (i.e., emotions, location, sensory associations, other memories, etc.), repetition of the memory over the course of time, and distractions or disruptions when the memory is being stored.

Category: IRC Social and Emotional Learning Competencies
Brief Description: Mindfulness is cross-cutting throughout IRC’s approach to SEL, addressing skills in all five competencies. Mindfulness is defined as: the state of being aware and focused on the present moment; accepting the present while being open and curious about what is happening around and inside us. Students learn the benefits of mindfulness for reducing feelings of anxiety and stress, focusing their attention and learning to persevere through hardship.
Being humble about achievements, presenting a realistic view of himself or herself, and avoiding boasting or acting superior to others
General emotional state and outlook
Description: The student's typical emotional tone, including general cheerfulness, contentment, and capacity for enjoyment in daily activities

Brief Description: being ready when arriving at school
Description: Most people have a set of behaviors or actions for the beginning of each day that generally follow in a usual order and are designed to complete necessary tasks in preparation for the day’s activities. They begin with arising with sufficient time to avoid being late for the start of school, work or other daytime obligations; routines may include activities such as toileting, hygiene, dressing appropriately, eating, gathering one’s necessary belongings, and departing in a timely fashion so as to arrive at the first appointment of the day. Typically these routines are well-established so that they occur relatively automatically, obviating the need for detailed thinking about each task. In some cases, the individual does some preparation the evening before, in order to assure prompt completion of morning routines.

Brief Description: Student keeps team members on track, suggests alternatives, and discusses options (can be as much about agreement as conflict).
Handling unfamiliar experiences
Description: The student's comfort level and ability to cope when facing new people, places, activities, or challenges.

Brief Description: Student interprets verbal and nonverbal communication efforts of others.
managing recurring thoughts or ideas
Description: Sustained, recurring, goal-directed thoughts or ideas assist in focussing attention and activity in support of completing a task. In addition to helping sustain attention or focus, revisiting the thought or idea supports problem-solving or re-working options necessary to achieve a goal. When these thoughts are persistent and intrusive, they interfere with social, behavioral, and/or cognitive function. Persistent thoughts may include perseveration on specific or irrelevant topics, numbers, words, sounds, or tasks.

Brief Description: We critically appreciate our own cultures and personal histories, as well as the values and traditions of others. We seek and evaluate a range of points of view, and we are willing to grow from the experience.
Tolerating frustrations presented by others or by situations without expressing irritation or hostility
persisting when undertaking tasks
Description: Perseverance is the ability to keep working on tasks, even in the face of obstacles such as distractions, difficulties, and delays. Determination and commitment to acquiring knowledge and skills is a powerful force for most youth, however, it requires the ability to stay focused on a task and continue working, even in the face of interference and disruptions.

Brief Description: identifying personal goals and reflecting on progress over time
Description: Personal goals refer to a student’s ability to set age-appropriate goals (academic, social, or personal) and reflect on progress. Goal setting can support motivation and self-direction when goals are realistic and supported. Difficulty may show as inability to identify goals, goals that are unrealistic, or limited reflection on what helped or hindered progress.

Brief Description: Reports of bodily discomfort
Description: The frequency of the student's complaints about headaches, stomachaches, or other physical symptoms without clear medical cause

Brief Description: Appropriateness of physical actions
Description: The extent to which a student's physical behavior toward others and property is safe

Brief Description: Difficulty staying still or seated
Description: Observable patterns of fidgeting, squirming, leaving seat, or excessive movement in situations requiring calm and stillness

Brief Description: causing injury to self
Description: Persistent thoughts of self-harm, especially thoughts that lead to actions causing harm, are always problematic, and usually require urgent attention. Self-harm may or may not have suicidal intent, although the risk for suicidal behavior is increased in the presence of self-harm. In moments of despair or incredible anger, typical individuals may rarely have thoughts of self-harm. However, these thoughts are readily recognized as inappropriate and quickly managed without any action directed toward self-harm.

Brief Description: causing physical or emotional harm to other persons
Description: Persistent thoughts of harm to others, especially those that lead to actions that cause harm are always problematic, and usually require urgent attention. Harm to others may also include emotional harm. Ideas about harming others usually has no homicidal intent, however, these wishes to cause physical or emotional harm to others may lead to serious consequences. As a result, in the presence of these thoughts, careful evaluations are necessary, and targets of the harmful thoughts (e.g., animals, children, other adults) should be protected until the potential threat has passed.

Brief Description: developing plans to complete tasks
Description: Planning and organization, often referred to as “executive functions,” make it possible to allocate cognitive and other resources to successfully sequence and complete tasks. Planning and organization are learned skills that require the appropriate application of attention, cognitive ability, and memoryin order to create and sustain a plan. This includes both short-term and long-term planning for projects, assignments, and other activities. It also includes the monitoring of these processes and plans in order to assure progress toward the desired goal. While younger children have difficulty with executive functions due to a limited concept of time, with maturity, it is possible to manage more and multiple complex tasks, with intermixed goals and objectives.

Brief Description: playing well alone and with others
Description: Play is a complex set of behaviors, largely for the purpose of enjoyment, but may also provide a tool for experimentation and problem-solving in a safe or non-competitive environment. Play activities include social and imaginary use of objects and relationships as well as opportunities to practice a full spectrum of social skills, behavioral control, problem solving and much more. The complexity and function of play develops along with the development of cognitive and motor function, routines and habits, knowledge and skills, and much more. Play takes place in individual and social contexts. It may include games and toys, as well as tools and tasks typically a part of daily work (e.g., pencils, cooking utensils, sports equipment, etc.). While these playful interactions may seem to be of little purpose, they are actually serious attempts at mastery, role-playing, and practice that sets the stage for real-life skills and activities. This actual nature of the practice varies as a result of a variety of factors including context, social relationships, and developmental age.

Brief Description: Having a purpose means being driven by something larger than yourself.
cognitive and mechanical elements of reading comprehension
Description: Reading is the ability to decode written symbols for purposes of communication and learning. While reading most commonly focuses on symbols referred to as “letters” or “characters” from alphabets, in fact, decoding any symbols is a form of reading, including symbols such as logos, flags, and other devices. Reading most languages requires understanding of components of writing include grammar, syntax, punctuation, sentences, paragraphs etc.

Category: Sesame Workshop Global Framework for Learning
Brief Description: Make connections. Children learn to process information, connect related information and prior knowledge, and then complete a task or solve a problem (e.g., our shoes are dirty so we need to wipe them on the mat before going indoors). Recognize cause and effect relationships. Children learn to recognize when one thing makes another thing happen (e.g., poking a bubble will make it pop). Compare, contrast, and sort. Children learn more about things by observing how certain characteristics are similar or different (e.g., color, shape, size, texture, or sound), and they classify, match, and sort objects based on those characteristics (e.g., putting all the blue objects into one group). Consider and choose from multiple solutions or options. Children learn to investigate multiple solutions or options to solve a problem. They think critically about each one and evaluate it, then choose the most appropriate or effective solution. Evaluate their choice. Children learn to reflect on the solution or decision they made and decide whether or not it was successful. If it was not the best choice, they may go back and try another option.
recognizing and understanding words and gestures as communication
Description: Receptive language is the capacity to comprehend verbal and non-verbal messages provided by others in the environment. It requires the ability to appreciate the nuances of communication (e.g., gesture, body posture, rhythm, volume, vocabulary, prosody, tone, etc.); each of these elements enhance the effectiveness and comprehension of communicative intent. In order to receive communication, the individual must attend to the critical elements of language, as well as the ability to focus on and interpret communication directed specifically at the individual, as well as more broadly with the environment. These skills grow in complexity over the course of the lifespan, however, there is considerable variability amongst individuals that depends on their biological make-up, cognitive ability, culture, and social experience.

Brief Description: Reflection describes the need to create and make meaning. It involves making sense of one’s own experiences, emotions and thoughts to create a sense of personal identity. Humans are conscious creatures; in fact, many philosophers have argued that the ability to reflect and take perspective is what makes humans unique.

The ability to establish and maintain healthy and rewarding relationships with diverse individuals and groups. This includes communicating clearly, listening actively, cooperating, resisting inappropriate social pressure, negotiating conflict constructively and seeking and offering help when needed.

Resilience has been defined as the ability to “bounce back” from adversity and thrive in the context of risk. Resilience refers to a pattern over time that is characterized by good eventual adaptation despite risk, stressors, or adversity. It also is defined by the ability to appropriately and realistically connect future goals and opportunities to one’s own abilities, and to adapt as needed to situational constraints. Resilient individuals cope well with stressors and do not get derailed by stressful events but persist and remain optimistic. Although there are individual differences in stress tolerance, resilience generally is a learned process that is facilitated through positive and supportive interactions with the environment. Conscientiousness and low Neuroticism are two of the Big Five traits that align with resilience, along with Grit, but it is the expression of these traits under difficult circumstances that is the defining feature of resilience.
Young person can resist negative peer pressure and dangerous situations.

Category: Singapore Framework for 21CC and Student Outcomes
Brief Description: A person demonstrates respect when he believes in his own self-worth and the intrinsic worth of all people.
using feedback or correction to adjust work and approach
Description: Response to feedback describes how a student reacts to guidance, correction, and suggestions for improvement. A helpful response includes listening, asking clarifying questions, trying again, and making adjustments over time. Difficulty may show as shutting down, arguing, becoming embarrassed, or ignoring feedback, even when it is delivered supportively.

Brief Description: adjusting behavior after reminders, cues, or corrections
Description: Response to redirection reflects how a student reacts when an adult provides a reminder or correction about expectations. Strong skills include acknowledging the cue, changing behavior, and returning to learning with minimal disruption. Difficulty may include arguing, escalating, needing multiple prompts, or showing lingering upset that interferes with re-engagement.

Brief Description: keeping track of materials and using belongings responsibly
Description: Responsibility for materials refers to managing personal and school items (e.g., notebooks, devices, supplies, assignments) and treating them with care. Strong responsibility supports readiness and reduces lost instructional time. Difficulty may be seen in frequent lost items, missing materials, damaged supplies, or needing repeated reminders to bring or return needed items.

Brief Description: accepting responsibility for actions taken by self or others
Description: Responsibility is the willingness and ability to appropriately manage or control self, situations and/or the actions of other individuals. The ability to assume responsibility begins with managing one’s own actions, emotions, and cognitions, then gradually expands to being more in control of interactions with others and broader elements of the environment. When faced with new tasks or uncertainty, there may be cautionary over-control followed by fading to a balance between self-control and sharing control with others.

Brief Description: taking chances to achieve goals when faced with possible failure embarrassment or harm
Description: Risk taking is the ability to overcome the possibility of failure, embarrassment, or harm in order to achieve a specific goal or to acquire a particular want or need. Appropriate risk taking requires a sensible analysis of the balance between outcomes and the possible consequences of a particular action.

Brief Description: Feelings about school and learning
Description: The student's overall orientation toward school, including enjoyment, perceived relevance, and sense of belonging

Brief Description: Connection to school environment
Description: A student's sense of feeling safe, welcome, and engaged at school—including enjoyment of being there and feeling like they matter to the school community

Brief Description: Young person is actively engaged in learning.
Gathering and interpreting observations, experimental data, and disciplinary content knowledge in order to predict and explain phenomena
managing screen-based activities including education games entertainment and social media
Description: “Screens” refers to devices such as computers, television, tablets, e-readers, smartphones, and hand-held video games. Regulation of screen time requires careful planning and coordination as the use of “screens” may play crucial roles in both academic and social life. Screen time has two components: duration and content. While some materials and exposures may be safe and appropriate, other can be quite dangerous.

Brief Description: recognizing strengths and weaknesses identifying emotions self reflection self confidence

Category: Social, Emotional, and Ethical (SEE) Learning Framework
Brief Description: Accept'oneself'and'one’s'emotions'by'understanding'their' context,'allowing'for'a'relaxation'of'self?judgment'
communicating needs and participating in decisions about learning supports
Description: Self-advocacy is a student’s ability to speak up about needs, preferences, and goals in appropriate ways. This may include requesting accommodations that are already in place, asking for clarification, or expressing when something is not working. Low self-advocacy may appear as silent struggling, relying on others to speak for them, or difficulty describing what kind of help would be useful.

Brief Description: responding to mistakes with kindness and realistic self-talk
Description: Self-compassion is the ability to treat oneself kindly when making mistakes or experiencing setbacks. In school, it supports persistence and willingness to try again. Low self-compassion may look like harsh self-criticism, shame, or giving up after small errors; healthy self-compassion allows students to acknowledge mistakes without seeing them as personal failure.

Brief Description: assessing one's belief in their ability
Description: Confidence is an individual’s belief in their own ability to take on and succeed at a task or challenge.

Brief Description: managing impulses and self-regulating behavior
Description: Effective social adaptations and goal seeking requires the ability to resist non-productive impulses and distractions that may interfere with achieving a goal. Self-control is the ability to manage the full spectrum of one’s behaviors in order to quickly, flexibly, and effectively adapt as one attempts to meet one’s personal and social needs. This means maintaining control over language, social, and motor behavior, while being sensitive and responsive to other environmental factors such as the behaviors of others who are sharing time and space. Self-control includes the ability to both behave proactively and reactively, as well as to inhibit unnecessary or inappropriate behavior.

Brief Description: A process in which learners take the initiative in planning, implementing and evaluating their own learning needs and outcomes, with or without the help of others.
recognizing one's own strengths and weaknesses
Description: Self-image is the internal sense of identity. It not only includes objective perception of self, along with wishes and aspirations as well as the notion of how one compares to others. The objective components of self-image include perceptions of how one looks, feels, thinks, and acts, placed in a cultural frame, that includes lessons learned from peers, family members, and the community (e.g., role models, social media, etc.).

Brief Description: checking own work and behavior
Description: Self-monitoring is the executive function skill of observing and evaluating one's own performance and behavior. It involves 'checking in' with oneself to see if the current actions are aligning with the goal (e.g., checking math problems for errors, noticing if one is talking too loudly). Effective self-monitoring allows for self-correction and improved accuracy and social appropriateness.

Brief Description: Awareness of inner processes and subjective experiences, such as thoughts and feelings, and the ability to reflect on and articulate such experiences.
responding to sensory input including touch taste smell sight hearing and somatic
Description: There is enormous individual variability in the perception and ability to interpret and respond to sensory input. Sensations typically includes the five senses (e.g., touch, taste, smell, sight, and hearing), however, somatic perceptions (e.g., pain, heart rate, respiratory rate, kinesthetics, etc.) are often sensed quite acutely, and can modulate emotions, cognitions, and behavior. Precision in the identification of sensory inputs and the reaction to them is essential for safe interactions with the environment as well as appropriate social function.

Brief Description: expressing age-appropriate sexual identity and behavior
Description: Sexual behavior includes behaviors that are related to an individual's particular individual “sexual identity.” While there are generally male and female biological differences amongst humans, there exists a broad spectrum of gender-related behaviors that are “assigned” or “learned,” based on cultural and social expectations in a community, not infrequently independent of “sex assigned at birth.” Some behaviors appear to be “assigned,” and are often considered “conventional.” When there are variations that don’t meet social expectations, it can cause discomfort - for children, peers, and/or adults - and can lead to adverse outcomes like bullying, discrimination and social isolation. Examples of these are so-called “effeminate” males or “masculine” females. Most “unconventional” gender behaviors are not abnormal but simply represent the broad variation in expressions of identity.

Brief Description: evidence of inadequate duration or quality of sleep including drowsiness and persistent lack of energy
Description: While the precise function of sleep is unknown, sleep appears to be a physiological state in which the brain rests and resets some of its functions. While the brain is engaged in sleep, the remainder of the human body also gets a chance to rest and recover from the physical exertion of the previous day. Sleep may also play a restorative role for physiologic, cognitive, and emotional functioning and wellbeing. Sleep has discrete stages, one of which allows for dreaming. Typically, individuals sleep varying amounts of time, ranging from 4-10 hours, usually, but not necessarily occurring at night. Daytime napping may also be a healthy component of sleep. One goal for sleep is to gain adequate amounts of rest to support ongoing activities during the waking hours. Pre-bedtime and bedtime routines are commonly associated with sleep, and may include social activities (e.g., story telling, prayers, reading, etc.). Sleep difficulties include either inadequate or excessive amounts of sleep, as well as excessive and inappropriate daytime drowsiness.

Brief Description: Seeking out and enjoying situations involving interpersonal interaction and building relationships with others

Social Awareness is the ability to take the perspective of and empathize with others from diverse backgrounds and cultures, to understand social and ethical norms for behavior, and to recognize family, school, and community resources and supports.
Ease in social interactions
Description: How comfortable and at ease a student feels when interacting with peers, adults, and people they don't know well

Brief Description: communication enabling social interactions
Description: Social functioning is the ability to share thoughts, needs, ideas, and behaviors. Social communication includes words and gestures in conjunction with an “invitation” to respond, as well as the willingness to receive and accept social responses. This leads to reciprocity, or “turn-taking,” the repeated exchanges of thoughts, needs, ideas, and behaviors that form the basis of conversation, discussion, collaborative work, and play.

Brief Description: cooperating in social interactions including play
Description: Cooperation is working together with other individuals, or in groups, to achieve a common goal or objective. This requires effective communication for sharing of thoughts, ideas, and plans, as well as a willingness to be flexible and context sensitive when sharing behaviors and communications.

Brief Description: engaging in social behavior
Description: Social engagement is the combination of intent to form and maintain social interactions combined with the appropriate and flexible application of social speech, cues, gestures, and behaviors (e.g., smiling, visual regard, hand shaking/bowing, etc.). Social engagement directs these behaviors toward individuals or groups, with the goal of establishing and maintaining reciprocal, social transactions and relationships.

Category: EU NESET Framework for Social and Emotional Education
Brief Description: Students have good relationship skills, being able to establish and maintain healthy and rewarding relationships based on co-operation and collaboration. They resist inappropriate social pressure; constructively prevent, manage and resolve interpersonal conflict; and seek and provide help when needed. They demonstrate ethical behaviour and responsible decision making in the various contexts they operate, considering the needs and rights of others in their behaviour and decisions. More specifically, this content area includes the following competencies. Healthy and rewarding relationships with individuals and groups, appreciating equality and diversity in relationships; Effective communication to express oneself and positive exchanges with others, using both verbal and nonverbal skills; Cooperation and collaboration with others; Leadership skills (motivating others, teamwork, negotiation, decision making); Dealing with peer pressure (refusing to engage in unwanted, unsafe and unethical conduct); Constructive conflict resolution (achieving mutually satisfactory resolutions to conflict by addressing the needs of all concerned); Dealing with negative relationships such as bullying, harassment and violence; Seeking and providing help and support; Ethical and responsible behaviour and decision making (considering ethical standards, safety concerns, and respect for others, and the likely consequences of various courses of action when making decisions); Contributing to the wellbeing and flourishing of the community.
Interacting appropriately
Description: The student's use of appropriate social behaviors such as sharing, taking turns, conversation skills, and reading social cues.

Brief Description: speaking understandably
Description: Speech is the production of sounds that are most often formed into words which can be linked to form sentences, paragraphs, descriptions, requests, stories, and much more. Using variations in rate, tone, rhythm, volume, clarity, word/sound selection, coordination with non-verbal communication, and other elements of sound production enhance the understandability of the intended communication. Flexible and adaptable speech offers greater possibility that the intended message will be received and properly interpreted by the listener.

Brief Description: speaking with an appropriate number of words for communication
Description: Language is the full spectrum of communicative behaviors. It includes words, gestures, body posture, facial expression, and a myriad of other behaviors that have communicative intent. This item refers ONLY to spoken language - speech. There is enormous variation in speech quantity that is partly dependent on context (“Is this a time to be quiet or a time to offer to speak up?”) and also depends on the capability of the individual to speak about specific content (“Does the individual know anything about the present topic?” “Are they lacking confidence with respect to that content?”) Or, does the individual have the physical ability to produce speech at all. Thus, the quantity of speech may typically vary depending on context and content, however, individuals with problems related to speech quantity have difficulty regulating the amount of speaking in appropriate response to the context or content.

Brief Description: managing tension resulting from challenges or demands
Description: Stress is a feeling of emotional or physical tension that is the body’s reaction to an internal or external challenge or demand. The internal factors can be thoughts, ideas, emotions, or even cognitive and emotional challenges. External factors may include leisure, work, or social demands. The response to stress can be both cognitive-emotional, as well as physiologic. Stress responses are adaptive when they are developmentally and behaviorally appropriate to the intensity, complexity, and duration of the demand or challenge.

Brief Description: Embodied in the stamina, grace and elegance of a ballerina or a shoemaker, is the desire for craftsmanship, mastery, flawlessness and economy of energy to produce exceptional results. People who value accuracy, precision and craftsmanship take time to check over their products. They review the rules by which they are to abide; they review the models and visions they are to follow; and they review the criteria they are to employ and confirm that their finish product matches the criteria exactly. To be craftsmanlike means knowing that one can continually perfect one's craft by working to attain the highest possible standards, and pursue ongoing learning in order to bring a laser like focus of energies to task accomplishment. These people take pride in their work and have a desire for accuracy as they take time to check over their work. Craftsmanship includes exactness, precision, accuracy, correctness, faithfulness, and fidelity. For some people, craftsmanship requires continuous reworking. Mario Cuomo, a great speechwriter and politician, once said that his speeches were never done—it was only a deadline that made him stop working on them!
using inappropriate substances including alcohol tobacco and cannabis
Description: Substance use is the consumption of chemicals that disrupt cognitive, behavioral, emotional, or other adaptive functioning. The most common substance use is alcohol and nicotine, but can also include a broad variety of substances, including the inappropriate use of prescribed medications. Persistent use of substances that leads to disruption in function is referred to as substance abuse. It is said that for some individuals, the recreational use of some substances may be acceptable, however, it is not clear who can safely use which substances. All evidence suggests that even the most benign of these medications and substances that are used inappropriately can have both short- and long-term disruptions in cognitive, behavioral, emotional, or other adaptive functioning, even modest doses, and may also be associated with significant general health complications. Addiction is a subset of substance abuse that is characterized by habitual, often uncontrollable use of substances, and a “withdrawal syndrome” when the substances are discontinued.

Brief Description: recognizing beginning structure and end of tasks
Description: It is typical to spontaneously take on tasks and willingly accept task assignments. Task completion is the ability to appreciate that all tasks have beginnings and ends, while also finding satisfaction in moving to and achieving a goal. Without fear, one recognizes that failure and/or inability to complete the task sometimes occurs. Managing failure and other disruptions is critical to consistent task completion, even in the face of potential disappointment.

Brief Description: beginning work promptly after instructions
Description: Task initiation is the ability to begin a task or activity in a timely manner without undue procrastination or hesitation. It requires the student to overcome inertia, understand the starting point, and generate the necessary energy to commence work. Difficulties in this area often manifest as 'stalling' even when the student has the skills to do the work.

Brief Description: Mastering modes of thinking that apply to broad classes of problems
Pausing to consider consequences
Description: The tendency to stop and think before speaking or acting, rather than immediately responding to urges or reacting without reflection

Brief Description: adapting thinking speed to meet situational demands
Description: The pace of adaptive thinking varies to meet the demands of the task. Multiple factors contribute to the enormous variation in thinking speed as individuals process information, including attention, intellectual ability, interests, familiarity, and memory, as well as environment and practice. It is important to manage thinking speed in order to allocate flexible amounts of time to appropriately address varying problems and challenges. Thinking faster is not always helpful as it may lead to errors, whereas thinking slowly may lead to missed opportunities. Finding successful balance in regulating thinking speed is essential for successful adaptation.

Brief Description: adapting social and other behaviors in response to tics or atypical movements
Description: Tics (repetitive motor behaviors), as well as disruptions in motor rhythm and coordination fluidity constitute atypical movements. Atypical movements may include fine or gross motor activity, involve very rapid to very slow movements, and have varying size of movements. Tics may involve facial muscles (e.g., twitching), trunk and limb muscle movements (e.g., head and shoulder shrugging), as well vocal tics (i.e., respiratory and laryngeal muscle movements yielding either sounds or words.) Atypical movements often make affected individuals feel sad, embarrassed, frustrated, and anxious; they often become victims of mockery, shaming, and bullying.

Brief Description: managing toileting behaviors and routines
Description: Managing toileting and hygiene is a basic social and behavioral skill that is essential for successful adaptive function. It includes self-management of excretions, as well as cleaning oneself. Intrinsic to managing toileting and hygiene, is a personal understanding of one’s own daily rhythms and the extent to which one can control them, in the context of other environmental events (e.g., school/work, leisure, sleep, meals etc.). Therefore successful toileting and hygiene includes proper scheduling and the use of socially-appropriate behaviors to complete toileting and hygiene tasks.

Brief Description: responding appropriately to differences in cultures and belief systems
Description: Tolerance is the willingness and ability to thoughtfully and fairly judge values and belief systems. This includes treating fairly, and with respect and courtesy, those with varied abilities and identities, as well as those from different cultures, values, and beliefs.

Brief Description: transitioning between activities or places
Description: Leaving home or other sites (e.g., school) requires preparation that is often captured in routines so that all the elements of the departure are well-coordinated, with little emotional or behavioral disruption, and no necessary items are left behind. It is important to anticipate pending transitions and plan for what comes next. The departure requires the timely gathering of objects necessary for the transition, so that the departure can take place in an orderly and timely fashion. Transitions routines often use appropriate social elements (e.g., “Good-bye,” “See you tomorrow,” “Thank you,” waving or hugs, etc.), as well as addressing of safety concerns (e.g., “hold my hand”, “put on your seat belt”, etc.)

Brief Description: having directly or indirectly experienced traumatic events
Description: In the course of typical, daily life, there are events of varying intensity that cause emotional or physical pain or disturbance (e.g., injury or death of a loved one). While upsetting and possibly causing “trauma-related symptoms,” they are not likely to lead to a trauma diagnosis. These symptoms generally resolve quickly and without long-term impact. On occasion, depending on the individual and the nature of the events, symptoms may persist. And, even more rarely, Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), may appear. Severe traumatic reactions are generally associated with events in which the individual’s health safety and/or life are in immediate jeopardy. Individuals are more likely to be affected the closer they are in time and space to traumatic events.

Brief Description: Openness to unfamiliar experiences
Description: The degree to which a student is willing to attempt new activities

Category: Hilton & Pellegrino Clusters of 21st Century Competencies
Brief Description: Initiative, self-direction, responsibility, perseverance, productivity, grit, Type 1 self- regulation (metacognitive skills, including forethought, performance, and self- reflection), professionalism/ ethics, integrity, citizenship, career orientation
managing worries and anxiety
Description: Worries are the result of fears or anxiety. The stimulus for worries can be internal or external. External worries often come from frightening or forbidden objects or events. Internal worries are often associated with self-doubt or lack of confidence, as well as legitimate concerns about objects or events from the past or anticipated in the future. Worries come in many forms, and while they generally reflect internal feeling states, they are commonly expressed as behaviors including the appearance of being anxious, excess vocalization of the worry, or avoidance.

Brief Description: cognitive and mechanical elements of written expression
Description: Writing is the graphical representation of ideas that consists of two separate and distinct actions. The first is the cognitive process of changing an idea into the symbols (letters, characters, or other) in preparation for writing. The second is the motor process of producing the “written” symbols that present an idea in whatever medium is chosen (paper, computer screen, etc.), in a fashion that is potentially comprehensible by others. While letters and complex symbols form the basis of developmentally sophisticated writing, the simple graphic productions (e.g., scribbles) of young children and others with limited skills, can be very effective communication tools.
